Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Arctic Land Fast Sea Ice Formation in the Presence of Fresh Water Input
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most notable changes in the Arctic during recent years has been the variability in sea ice extent and timing. Changes in the character and seasonal cycle of nearshore sea ice is of particular importance to indigenous communities that use the nearshore sea ice as a platform for subsistence hunting and transportation. Observations and model projections also suggest increasing freshwater runoff to the coastal ocean from increased melting of glaciers and ice sheets, thawing of permafrost, and precipitation over land. This runoff impacts the sea ice that forms in the fall. Sea ice formed under freshwater influence reveals differences in salinity, porosity, and permeability, and thus its optical and mechanical properties. This project will provide unique observations of sea ice formation and structure under conditions of freshwater influence.

This project will contribute to STEM workforce development through provision of support for the training of a graduate student. It will also entrain undergraduate students from Dartmouth?s Women in Science Project (WISP). One undergraduate will participate in the spring field work. The project will also apply for support for a PolarTREC teacher. K-12th grade outreach activities will be offered and will leverage existing programs at University of Washington such as participation in the Polar Science Weekend at the Pacific Science Center.

The freshwater discharge to the coastal ocean affects thermodynamic processes in sea ice by changing salinity and temperature of the waters undergoing freezing. This three-year pilot project is designed to study sea ice formation and structure in the coastal ocean, while addressing the following important questions:
1. How do microstructure and the brine pocket network differ in sea ice that forms and grows where there is significant fresh water input compared to sea ice in the open ocean?
2. Can we monitor the onset of freezing, freezing rate and ice type in situ in sensitive nearshore areas, while collecting data remotely?
3. How does microstructure affect heat transfer along the length of an ice core?
The project will combine recently developed observation and sampling technologies, and integrate expertise in field monitoring, and physical and chemical sea ice characterization. Sea ice formation, growth rate, and salinity will be monitored in situ at a location of freshwater input during the course of a growth season using a wire ladder. Oxygen isotopic ratios and optical thin section stratigraphy will be used to quantify freshwater influence. X-ray micro-computed tomography will be used to characterize porosity and brine channel topology at 1 cm intervals along ice cores and provide quantitative data on microstructural differences in ice influenced by the freshwater. Laboratory tests and modeling will be used to examine heat transfer through sea ice cores held at their in situ temperature gradient, as a function of microstructural stratigraphy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most notable changes in the Arctic has been the spatial variability in sea ice extent and timing of sea ice growth and retreat.  Changes in the character and seasonal cycle of nearshore sea ice is of particular importance to indigenous communities that use the nearshore sea ice as a platform for subsistence hunting and transportation.  Observations and computer model projections also suggest increasing freshwater runoff to the coastal ocean from increased melting of glaciers and ice sheets, thawing of permafrost, and precipitation over land.  This runoff impacts the sea ice that forms in the fall.  Sea ice formed under freshwater influence reveals differences in salinity, porosity, and permeability, and thus its optical and mechanical properties.  The freshwater discharge to the coastal ocean affects thermodynamic processes in sea ice by changing salinity and temperature of the waters undergoing freezing.  This three-year pilot project was designed to development an instrument that can study sea ice formation in areas of freshwater flow into the Arctic Ocean in order to observe the microstructure of ice salinity and temperature (MIST) of land fast sea ice as it grows from fall through the winter and spring to improve our understanding of physical processes and improve computer model projections of climate change. 

During the first year (2016) of the project, we developed and tested two prototype MIST buoys named after Alaskan rivers Adak and Eyak (Fig. 1), and deployed them in Elson Lagoon near Utqiaġvik, Alaska in during freeze up October 2017 (Figs. 2 and 3). These buoys froze into the sea ice, reported hourly meteorological and MIST measurements to the science team back in their labs using the Iridium Satellite constellation until they were recovered in March 2018 (Fig. 4). During the deployment and recovery of these buoys, measurements and samples of ocean water and sea ice cores were collected, and we surveyed the snow at both recovery sites (Fig. 5). We then analyzed the microstructure, chemistry and isotopic composition of the ice cores for comparison to the measurements made by the prototype MIST buoys. We have also compared in situ observations with satellite images of the deployment sites. We have presented our results in academic seminars at our institutions and at scientific conferences, one undergraduate research thesis was written, and a paper has been submitted to a peer reviewed journal documenting the development of the MIST buoys.

During this project we mentored 5 undergraduate students in our labs, brought 3 of these students to join us during field work in Utqiaġvik, Alaska, and supported a post-doctoral position for Dr. Alice Bradley who is now an Assistant Professor at Williams College.

While completing fieldwork in Alaska, and Inuvik, Canada, the team visited the Middle and High Schools to share our research with the local community. At Barrow Middle School to requested support for a citizens? science project, where students sent the Dartmouth lab melted sea ice and seawater samples throughout the year. This not only benefits the project?s scientific breadth, but also engages children to play an essential role in research directly impacting their home.  

In March 2019, we helped NBC with #AlInTheArctic for the Today Show, which highlighted the impacts of climate change on coastal communities in the Arctic and shared this with their broader audience (Fig. 6, left).
